natural problem: Find the largest negative integer $x$ which satisfies the congruence $34x+6\equiv 2\pmod {20}$.
natural solution: We can simplify the congruence as follows (all of the following congruences are equivalent): \begin{align} 34x+6&\equiv 2\pmod {20}\\ 14x+6&\equiv 2\pmod {20}\\ 14x&\equiv 16\pmod {20}\\ 7x&\equiv 8\pmod {10}\\

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: int
assumes h0 : "(34 * x + 6) mod 20 = 2"
shows  "x = -6"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the largest negative integer $x$ which satisfies the congruence $34x+6\equiv 2\pmod {20}$. The final Answer is -6
 ### Proof
 We can simplify the congruence as follows (all of the following congruences are equivalent): \begin{align} 34x+6&\equiv 2\pmod {20}\\ 14x+6&\equiv 2\pmod {20}\\ 14x&\equiv 16\pmod {20}\\ 7x&\equiv 8\pmod {10}\\
 21x&\equiv 8\cdot 3\pmod {10}\\ x&\equiv 24\pmod{10}\\ x&\equiv 4\pmod{10}\\ x&\equiv \boxed{-6}\pmod{10}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: int
assumes h0 : "(34 * x + 6) mod 20 = 2"
shows  "x = -6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find an integer $x$ such that when $34x + 6$ is divided by $20$, the remainder is $2$. The final answer is $-6$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: int
assumes h0 : "(34 * x + 6) mod 20 = 2"
and h1 : "x < 0"
shows  "x = -6"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the largest negative integer $x$ which satisfies the congruence $34x+6\equiv 2\pmod {20}$. The final Answer is -6
 ### Proof
 We can simplify the congruence as follows (all of the following congruences are equivalent): \begin{align} 34x+6&\equiv 2\pmod {20}\\ 14x+6&\equiv 2\pmod {20}\\ 14x&\equiv 16\pmod {20}\\ 7x&\equiv 8\pmod {10}\\
 21x&\equiv 8\cdot 3\pmod {10}\\ x&\equiv 24\pmod{10}\\ x&\equiv 4\pmod{10}\\ x&\equiv \boxed{-6}\pmod{10}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: int
assumes h0 : "(34 * x + 6) mod 20 = 2"
and h1 : "x < 0"
shows  "x = -6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find an integer $x$ such that $x$ is less than 0 and the remainder when $34x + 6$ is divided by 20 is 2. The final answer is $x = -6$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: int
assumes h0 : "(34 * x + 6) mod 20 = 2 mod 20"
shows  "(GREATEST x. x < 0 \<and> (34 * x + 6) mod 20 = 2 mod 20) = -6"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the largest negative integer $x$ which satisfies the congruence $34x+6\equiv 2\pmod {20}$. The final Answer is -6
 ### Proof
 We can simplify the congruence as follows (all of the following congruences are equivalent): \begin{align} 34x+6&\equiv 2\pmod {20}\\ 14x+6&\equiv 2\pmod {20}\\ 14x&\equiv 16\pmod {20}\\ 7x&\equiv 8\pmod {10}\\
 21x&\equiv 8\cdot 3\pmod {10}\\ x&\equiv 24\pmod{10}\\ x&\equiv 4\pmod{10}\\ x&\equiv \boxed{-6}\pmod{10}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: int
assumes h0 : "(34 * x + 6) mod 20 = 2 mod 20"
shows  "(GREATEST x. x < 0 \<and> (34 * x + 6) mod 20 = 2 mod 20) = -6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find the greatest negative integer $x$ such that $(34x + 6)$ leaves the same remainder as $2$ when divided by $20$. The final Answer is $-6$.
